Literature Review: Leadership and creativity have become increasingly intertwined concepts in organizational research, as companies seek to foster innovation and maintain competitive advantage in rapidly evolving markets. This literature review explores the complex relationship between leader thinking, follower thinking, and creative performance, with a focus on how leaders can influence and enhance creativity within their organizations.The importance of creativity and innovation in organizational success has been well-established in the literature. Amabile (1996) proposed a componential theory of creativity, emphasizing the role of intrinsic motivation, domain-relevant skills, and creativity-relevant processes in fostering creative performance. Building on this foundation, researchers have sought to understand how leadership can cultivate these components and drive creative outcomes.Leadership styles have been found to significantly impact follower creativity. Transformational leadership, characterized by inspirational motivation and intellectual stimulation, has been consistently linked to enhanced creative performance among followers (Shin & Zhou, 2003). Leaders who exhibit transformational behaviors can inspire their followers to think outside the box and challenge existing paradigms, thereby fostering a culture of innovation within their teams.However, the relationship between leadership and creativity is not always straightforward. Zhang and Bartol (2010) introduced the concept of empowering leadership, which involves delegating authority and providing autonomy to followers. Their research demonstrated that empowering leadership can positively influence employee creativity by enhancing psychological empowerment and intrinsic motivation. This suggests that leaders must strike a delicate balance between providing guidance and allowing freedom for creative exploration.The role of leader cognition in fostering creativity has also garnered attention. Mumford et al. (2002) proposed that leaders of creative efforts must possess complex cognitive skills to effectively guide and support creative problem-solving. These skills include problem definition, information gathering, concept selection, and idea evaluation. Leaders who demonstrate proficiency in these areas are better equipped to facilitate creative processes within their teams and organizations.Furthermore, the concept of creative leadership has emerged as a distinct approach to fostering innovation. Sternberg (2007) defined creative leadership as the generation of ideas that are novel, high in quality, and task-appropriate. Creative leaders not only encourage creativity in others but also actively contribute to the creative process themselves, serving as role models and catalysts for innovation.The organizational context in which creativity occurs is another crucial factor influencing creative performance. Amabile et al. (1996) identified several workplace factors that can either support or inhibit creativity, including organizational encouragement, supervisory encouragement, work group supports, freedom, and resources. Leaders play a pivotal role in shaping these environmental factors to create a climate conducive to creativity and innovation.Recent research has also highlighted the importance of leader emotional intelligence in fostering creativity. Zhou and George (2003) found that emotionally intelligent leaders are better able to recognize and manage emotions in themselves and others, which can lead to increased employee creativity. By creating a psychologically safe environment where followers feel comfortable taking risks and expressing novel ideas, emotionally intelligent leaders can significantly enhance creative performance.The impact of leader-member exchange (LMX) on creativity has also been explored in the literature. High-quality LMX relationships, characterized by trust, respect, and mutual obligation, have been found to positively influence employee creativity (Tierney et al., 1999). Leaders who develop strong relationships with their followers are more likely to provide the support and resources necessary for creative endeavors.As organizations increasingly rely on teams for creative problem-solving, the role of leadership in fostering team creativity has gained prominence. Shin and Zhou (2007) found that transformational leadership can enhance team creativity by promoting team creative efficacy and team creative identity. Leaders who can effectively manage team dynamics and leverage diverse perspectives are better positioned to drive creative outcomes at the group level.In conclusion, the literature reveals a complex interplay between leader thinking, follower thinking, and creative performance. Effective leaders must not only possess the cognitive skills necessary to guide creative problem-solving but also create an environment that nurtures and supports creativity at individual, team, and organizational levels. Future research should continue to explore the specific mechanisms through which leaders can enhance follower creativity and investigate how leadership development programs can be tailored to cultivate the skills necessary for fostering innovation in today's dynamic business landscape.
